text: 2023 Observability Forecast Spotlight
label: H1

text: New Relic partnered with Enterprise Technology Research (ETR) for the third annual
label: body

text: Observability Forecast report, which examines the state and future of observability. We
label: body

text: surveyed 1,700 technology professionals in 15 countries across Asia Pacific, Europe,
label: body

text: and North America to learn about the business value of observability, its return on
label: body

text: investment (ROI), and its impact on costs and revenue. The report also benchmarks
label: body

text: service-level metrics like outage frequency, mean time to detection (MTTD), mean
label: body

text: time to resolution (MTTR), and cost.
label: body

text: Looking at Australia and New Zealand (ANZ) in particular, the top observability driver
label: body

text: was an increased focus on security, governance, risk, and compliance, while the top
label: body

text: observability benefits were increased operational efficiency, improved system uptime
label: body

text: and reliability, and security vulnerability management. View a summary of the
label: body

text: highlights and key findings for ANZ below, or dive right into the data .
label: body

text: Top takeaways from the largest, most
label: body

text: comprehensive observability study

text: State of Observability for Financial Services and Insurance
label: body

text: Financial institutions are experiencing an incredible transformation,
label: body

text: stemming from consumers expecting a higher level of digital interaction
label: body

text: and access to services and a lower dependency on physical services.
label: body

text: Increasing disintermediation and local and global financial services
label: body

text: industry (FSI) players such as Apple Pay, Revolut, and neo-banks are
label: body

text: feeding consumers’ desires to complete transactions online, including
label: body

text: from mobile devices, whether that’s checking bank balances, making
label: body

text: mobile deposits, getting a quote, tracking budgets, paying bills, making
label: body

text: purchases, or transferring funds.
label: body

text: At the same time, FSI organizations are faced with increased regulation,
label: body

text: with new mandates for IT and cyber risk management such as the Digital
label: body

text: Operational Resilience Act (DORA).
label: body

text: All of these factors drive unprecedented pressure on modernizing core
label: body

text: software, dematerialization, and scaling the digital infrastructure while
label: body

text: delivering optimal uptime, reliability, performance, customer experience,
label: body

text: and innovation.
label: body

text: Traditional financial institutions are in a race to modernize so they can
label: body

text: remain relevant and competitive amidst a flurry of trends like fintech,
label: body

text: insurtech, automation, mobile, and digital native. Many institutions
label: body

text: are accelerating their migration toward digital-native and digital-first
label: body

text: models rapidly.
label: body

text: In their quest to create a fluid, reliable, and efficient digital customer
label: body

text: experience (DCX) at all times, financial services and insurance institutions
label: body

text: are dealing with increasingly complex tech stacks. To ensure development
label: body

text: and innovation proceed at the required speed with a customer-centric
label: body

text: focus, they’re turning to observability to provide real-time visibility into
label: body

text: their infrastructure and software architecture, allowing for faster, more
label: body

text: accurate decision-making, accelerated innovation, and improved system
label: body

text: uptime and reliability.
label: body

text: This report focuses on the adoption and business value of observability
label: body

text: across the FSI and insurance sectors. It’s based on insights derived
label: body

text: from 176 respondents surveyed in association with the 2023
label: body

text: Observability Forecast .
label: body

text: Banks have traditionally had strong resiliency in their
label: body

text: systems and a relatively slow pace of change and software
label: body

text: developments for their core systems. So whenever they
label: body

text: get high-business-impact outages, they tend to be more
label: body

text: complex and therefore have a higher business impact and
label: body

text: time to resolve.
label: body

text: In fact, we observe this in most industries. Once an
label: body

text: organization can resolve and eliminate a large number of
label: body

text: incidents with mature observability practices proactively,
label: body

text: they’re usually left with the more complex and unpredictable
label: body

text: ones that take longer to resolve, even if they could detect
label: body

text: them early and understand them quickly.
label: body

text: However, despite the relatively high MTTR, 64% said
label: body

text: MTTR has improved to some extent since adopting an
label: body

text: observability solution.
label: body

text: Notably, financial services/insurance organizations with full-
label: body

text: stack observability were more likely to report faster MTTD for
label: body

text: high-business-impact outages than organizations that had
label: body

text: not achieved full-stack observability. For instance, more than
label: body

text: half (51%) of those with an MTTD of 30 minutes or less for
label: body

text: high-business-impact outages had full-stack observability,
label: body

text: and 58% of those with an MTTD of five minutes or less had
label: body

text: full-stack observability.
label: body

text: More than a third (35%) of financial services/insurance
label: body

text: respondents said critical business app outages cost more
label: body

text: than $500,000 per hour—which was higher than average and
label: body

text: third highest overall compared to other industries—and 22%
label: body

text: estimated they cost their organizations more than $1 million
label: body

text: an hour.
label: body

text: Therefore, despite having a lower-than-average outage
label: body

text: frequency and MTTD, the higher-than-average MTTR
label: body

text: and hourly outage cost for financial services/insurance
label: body

text: organizations translated to a median annual outage cost
label: body

text: of $10.44 million, which is about 35% higher than the $7.75
label: body

text: million annual outage cost across all industries and fourth
label: body

text: highest overall.
label: body

text: FSI is a high-stakes business with a potentially large cost
label: body

text: average per transaction for some areas of the financial
label: body

text: sector, such as global corporate wire transfers and money
label: body

text: movements, trading, and so on, so it’s not illogical that the
label: body

text: cost of incidents is high in this vertical.

text: Summary
label: H1

text: Financial services/insurance organizations are going through a significant
label: body

text: market transformation, weathering new regulations and vying for customers
label: body

text: while remaining focused on delivering new products and services. To keep this
label: body

text: all in balance, they use observability to ensure uptime, reliability, performance,
label: body

text: efficiency, a seamless customer experience, and cutting-edge innovation.
label: body

text: Insights from the State of Observability for Financial Services and Insurance
label: body

text: report show that organizations in the industry understand the business value
label: body

text: of observability and are investing more in it. To keep organizations secure
label: body

text: while modernizing and innovating at a rapid pace, engineers rely heavily on
label: body

text: observability to ensure end-to-end visibility across complicated tech stacks.
label: body

text: The data also indicate that financial services/insurance organizations
label: body

text: are starting to consolidate monitoring tools. Given their strong interest
label: body

text: in deploying more capabilities in the next few years, signs point to these
label: body

text: organizations moving from point solutions to more robust platforms that
label: body

text: provide end-to-end visibility.

text: THE BOTTOM LINE
label: H2

text: Small to mid-sized businesses (SMBs) face a number of challenges in today’s marketplace.
label: body

text: Under pressure to remain competitive while cutting costs, SMBs adopt ERP systems to
label: body

text: diversify their business models, enable descriptive and predictive analytics, and improve
label: body

text: supply chain operations. Furthermore, SMBs have less tolerance for drawn-out
label: body

text: implementation projects and continuous ERP consulting spend to configure and adapt their
label: body

text: systems. To address these challenges, ERP vendors invest in industry-specific ERP packages,
label: body

text: self-service tooling for extensibility and analytics, and solutions to support HR and Sales. As
label: body

text: the footprint of an ERP system within an organization grows, so too does the potential value
label: body

text: and risk. SMBs must consider the hidden costs of an ERP system as part of their evaluation,
label: body

text: such as data storage, customization, training, and maintenance.
label: body

text: NucleusResearch.com
label: body

text: Document Number: X119 June 2023
label: body

text: OVERVIEW
label: H2

text: Small to mid-sized businesses (SMBs) are coping with the shifting market by diversifying
label: body

text: their business models; manufacturers pivot to distribution and retail, distributors perform
label: body

text: light assembly and packaging, and service organizations add subscription or consumption
label: body

text: pricing models. Legacy ERPs or lightweight accounting systems lack the functionality and

text: flexibility to support these initiatives; therefore, organizations turn towards ERP
label: body

text: modernization. Another factor driving ERP adoption is to enable descriptive and predictive
label: body

text: analytics. ERP systems touch many areas of a business where a fast-growing company may
label: body

text: not have implemented a software system to manage and collect data. By deploying an ERP,
label: body

text: companies will have a central repository for financial, operational, workforce, and sales data
label: body

text: to leverage for analytics. Organizations also purchase ERP to assist supply chain operations.
label: body

text: As the business models of SMBs diversify, the complexity of their supply chains has
label: body

text: increased to where they can no longer solely rely on spreadsheets, swivel chair operations,
label: body

text: and best-guess decision-making. Where supply chain management technology vendors
label: body

text: typically cater to the mid-market and above, businesses under $100M in annual revenue
label: body

text: regularly turn to their ERPs for planning and execution functionality.
label: body

text: Regarding catering to the needs of the SMB market, ERP vendors have focused on
label: body

text: shortening time-to-value and lowering the total cost of ownership through industry-specific
label: body

text: offerings and self-service analytics, extensibility, and configuration tools. Virtually all ERP
label: body

text: vendors will claim to offer industry-focused packages with workflows, reports, and
label: body

text: dashboards pre-configured for specific use cases to remove much of the grunt work during
label: body

text: the implementation. Customers will be bombarded during the selection process about
label: body

text: these out-of-the-box capabilities; therefore, they must investigate how in-depth and well-
label: body

text: matched the pre-packaged systems are and how much configuration work must be done.
label: body

text: Many vendors have added self-service analytics designed for business users to help
label: body

text: organizations access advanced analytics without data scientists. These tools allow users to
label: body

text: select, clean, and transform data with a wizard-like approach to slice and dice data as
label: body

text: needed, select the best-fit model, collaborate with stakeholders, and generate visuals and
label: body

text: reports. As customers evaluate the analytic functionality of their ERPs, they must consider
label: body

text: the platform’s ability to integrate with other systems and govern data across the ecosystem
label: body

text: because the analysis users perform regularly requires data from multiple departments with
label: body

text: disparate solutions. For example, an ERP system only capable of overnight batch processing
label: body

text: will not support real-time dashboards. Self-service extensibility and configuration tooling are
label: body

text: essential to customers that want to limit their ERP consulting spend. No-code functionality
label: body

text: enables tech-savvy business users to construct workflows, automation, and reports that span
label: body

text: multiple departments or source data from systems outside their ERP.
label: body

text: In this Technology Value Matrix, Nucleus assesses the SMB-focused ERP market based on
label: body

text: the value customers realize from the product usability and functionality that vendors are
label: body

text: delivering with their solutions (Nucleus Research V67 – Understanding the Value Matrix,
label: body

text: April 2021). The Matrix is a snapshot of the market designed to help customers and
label: body

text: prospects understand where vendors are differentiating in how they deliver value and where
label: body

text: vendors are making significant product investments.
label: body

text: ACUMATICA
label: H2

text: Acumatica is recognized as a leader in this year’s SMB ERP Technology Value Matrix.
label: body

text: Acumatica’s cloud ERP solution is engineered to be easy to deploy, with a large ecosystem
label: body

text: of ISVs to meet the needs of the mid-market. Its ERP platform includes accounting, sales,
label: body

text: inventory, warehouse management, project management, customer management, and
label: body

text: shopfloor applications, built on an open and secure cloud architecture. This provides users
label: body

text: with constant availability, seamless remote collaboration, and enterprise-grade security.
label: body

text: Acumatica customers have the freedom to switch between public and private cloud
label: body

text: deployments as their business needs evolve. The vendor’s licensing policy further drives
label: body

text: flexibility and scalability by providing users with an unlimited, consumption-based license,
label: body

text: free of user-constraints. Acumatica has a single code base which can be delivered in
label: body

label: body

label: body

label: body

text: cross-module workflows, providing an uninterrupted operational experience.
